captions.text: Meet me in the gazebo at midnight, and don't bring anyone.
Oh hello! I didn't see you there.
I would have seen you if you were a car though.
Did you know they're over two hundred and 40 million cars in the United States alone? That's like, a whole bunch.
Which makes me wonder...
What if we stopped driving?
First and foremost thirty three thousand lives could have possibly been saved.
That many people were killed by cars in the U.S. in 2012.
Making your car one of the most dangerous places you can put your little body.
That's like a college football stadium full of people.
Imagine a stadium full of people who just cheated death. Look how happy they are.
Beyonce is performing for them... for free!
When's the last time you heard that word?
We're constantly flushing money into our cars.
Car payments, and gas, maintenance... it sure adds up.
To on average 10,181 dollars a year per person in the U.S.
Now multiply that by all the registered cars in the United States.
That is a whole lot of dough!
There is some bad news though...
The U.S. automotive industry employs approximately 3.9 million people.
If we stopped driving cars we'd also stop buying them. So those fine folks would be out of a job... but only temporarily.
With cars out of the picture the entire population would have to use public transportation.
More systems would need to be built and maintained resulting in... You guessed it! More jobs.
You're so smart!
According to a recent study public transportation allowed commuters to save about 21 billion dollars in 2012 nationally.
That's 42 million iPads! You could build a mansion only using iPads.
It's not just your money that would be saved. If people stopped driving altogether we would be relieving the environment of a great stress.
Every step of a car's life has an enormous environmental foot print. No cars means no footprint! Which means more trees and shade and flowers.
Studies show that transportation emissions account for 1/3 of the U.S. air pollution.
So without cars the sky would be 1/3 more clear.
That means people in LA might be able to see the beach... might.
It's also widely believed that many wars are fought for oil... Oil we need to power our cars!
Am I saying without cars there'd be no war?
I'm not... but without cars we would only fight for the most important reasons, like which way is the right way to hang the toilet paper roll?
Well there you have it! Fewer cars better earth! So maybe just ride a bike next time.
Yes hello driver? Bring the car around please.
Thank you so much.

comments.author: vicesat

comments.text:
Is it just me, or do people like to point fingers at cars when the subject 
of pollution and global warming comes up? Seriously, why can't people see 
that there are more upsides to cars than there are downsides? First off, 
what's done is done. We've got pollution, and we're stuck with it. Plus, 
it's no were near being entirely the automobile's fault. Even if we did 
manage to get rid of all cars, we'd still be producing millions of 
products, causing pollution. War wouldn't go away either. We've had war 
since ancient times, long before the automobile was even considered being 
made. War is horrid these days, thanks to our governments and their stupid 
nuclear weapons. Nuclear weapons because of cars? I don't think so. Without 
cars, we'd also be more prone to threats, such as robbers. Cars have doors 
you can lock, bicycles don't have doors. Life would also be more difficult 
for banks and museums. No cars means no armored vehicles, making it more 
risky to transport valuables. It would also take absolutely forever to 
receive packages. We couldn't exactly make buildings in cities closer 
together either. Especially big cities such as NYC. Try moving a bunch of 
skyscrapers closer together. Even if we could do this, our cities would 
become more congested, thanks to less space. And to finish off, all the 
work we've done to innovate cars to make them safer and more efficient 
would be completely lost. Years and years of hard work from engineers would 
be totally wasted. Thanks for reading.﻿

comments.author: Musiclistener196

comments.text:
This video is very naiive and impractical.  Many jobs require that you 
drive, and public transportation is not an option.  And I don't mean just 
jobs like race car drivers or cab drivers.  Also, those "new jobs" would 
only be temporary, so a LOT of people would be jobless, including people 
like race car drivers.  And even without all that pollution, the sky 
wouldn't be 1/3 clearer- that's not how it works.  And there wouldn't be 
more trees- trees NEED CO2.  It's not like we cut down trees to make cars. 
 We've also never fought a war over oil- we have fought battles over oil, 
but not wars.  We fight wars over freedom.  I know this isn't an orderly 
comment, but those are just some things that stuck out to me.  So do  a 
little thinking before you spew your outrageous ignorance.  The only good 
things that could come from a lack of cars would be cleaner air and MAYBE 
less obesity(assuming people biked and ran more).﻿
